'''Maryse Marpsat''' (born 1951) is a [[France|French]] [[sociologist]] and [[statistician]] whose work employs methods drawn from [[sociology]] and [[statistics]] but also [[mathematics]]. Her major sociological works concern [[poverty]], inequality and [[homeless]] situation. She is a civil servant, administrator of the French National Institute of Statistics ([[INSEE]]) and a fellow of the CSU, a French research institute specializing in sociological studies in urban societies.

Between 1983 and 1993, as a fellow of two French-British groups, the ''Cambridge Group for the History of Population and Social Structure'' and the ''Centre for Economic Policy Research'' in Cambridge, she worked to develop the comparisons of the household ways of living in France and England, particularly with [[Richard Wall (sociologist)|Richard Wall]] and [[Bruce Penhale]], from the ''City University'' of London.<ref>Cf. the preparation of the international colloquium ''Beyond national statistics : household and family patterns in comparative perspective'', London in April 1989, see its acts in ''Insee-Méthodes'', n° 8, février 1991</ref>

Since 2007, Maryse Marpsat is giving some courses on the topics of her researches. She focuses her last teaching, first, on relationships between statistic tools and their outcomes, and second, on "unequalities", their range, their origins and the different ways of their evaluation.<ref>Cf. the web site [http://www.ehess.fr/fr/enseignement/enseignements/2011/ue/619/ teachings of EHESS]</ref> Moreover, since 2007, she has provided on a monthly base some research workshops in her Institute of statistics, for example in 2012 going threw the feeling of inequalities either for owners of the French minimum wage called "RSA" or for retired people.<ref>See the [http://calenda.revues.org/nouvelle21216.html list of her seminars in the INSEE].</ref>
